para.paratext: Historically, in Georgia, character evidence of prior bad acts could not be admitted unless the defendant placed his character in issue by showing good character as a defense. In 2005, the Georgia legislature amended former O.C.G.A. § 24-9-20(b) to remove the language addressing the general bad character and prior convictions of a criminal defendant. As rewritten, the statute provided that a criminal defendant who testified could be examined and cross-examined as any other witness. Thus, if the defendant chose to testify, evidence of general bad character could be introduced without the defendant first introducing evidence of his good character. This provision was carried over into new O.C.G.A. § 24-5-506.[1]

A defendant may always introduce evidence of his good character and, if requested, he is entitled to a charge that evidence of good character alone may raise a reasonable doubt of his guilt.[2] Generally, the defendant will be limited to reputation evidence[3] unless he testifies, in which case, the defendant may also place his good character in issue through testimony of specific acts demonstrating his good character.[4]

Obviously, a defendant who offers witness testimony about his good reputation or cross-examines a state witness about the defendant's good character[5] puts his character in issue.[6] However, a defendant does not necessarily put his character in issue with inadvertent statements regarding his good conduct.[7] For example, testimony at trial regarding a defendant's “ten-year career as a teacher, his part-time job teaching homebound students, his part-time job teaching a GED [general equivalency diploma] program for inmates at a nearby prison, his counseling of the victim, and his attempt to find foster care for the victim” were insufficient to place his good character in issue and warrant a charge on the issue.[8] In another case, a defendant's testimony that he had been “in some trouble” was insufficient to put his character in issue[9] and evidence of bad character or prior convictions were not admissible against him.[10]

The prosecution may attack the defendant's character through general reputation or opinion testimony or cross examination of the defendant's character witnesses if the defendant places his character in issue. The prosecution may also introduce the defendant's previous convictions for crimes involving “dishonesty or making a false statement.”[11] Such evidence is limited to acts that reflect on the defendant's ability to testify truthfully.[12]

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(a)(1), if the accused presents evidence of any pertinent general or specific character trait, the prosecution may offer evidence to rebut the particular trait presented. However, under the new Code, convictions based upon nolo contendere pleas and generally evidence of most juvenile adjudications is not admissible.[13]

Also, the prosecution can rebut a material fact to which a witness testifies even if the rebuttal implies bad character. Thus, if a defense witness testifies that the defendant has never sold drugs, the prosecution may rebut with evidence of the defendant's prior convictions for selling cocaine.[14]

The mention that a defendant has been in jail[15] or other passing references to his criminal record[16] do not place his character at issue. Furthermore, the defendant's character is not placed in issue simply because a witness gives a nonresponsive answer to a question impacting negatively on the defendant's character.[17] Moreover, the defendant's propensity to carry firearms does not impute to him bad character.[18]

On the other hand, a statement by a defendant charged with driving his vehicle into a police car that he didn't “hit; no g****** pig” was deemed to be inadmissible at the man's DUI trial because it was an improper comment on his deficient character without relevance to any other issue or fact in dispute.[19]

Fed. R. Evid. 404(a) controls the admissibility of character evidence against a criminally accused in federal practice. The federal rule is similar to the previous Georgia rule in that both allow the criminal defendant to offer evidence of a pertinent character trait and the prosecution to rebut it. However, the federal rule limits the prosecution's rebuttal to the specific character traits raised by the defense.[20]
O.C.G.A. § 24-5-506(b) provides:

If an accused in a criminal proceeding wishes to testify and announces in open court his or her intention to do so, the accused may so testify. If an accused testifies, he or she shall be sworn as any other witness and, except as provided in Code Sections 24-6-608 and 24-6-609, may be examined and cross-examined as any other witness. The failure of an accused to testify shall create no presumption against the accused, and no comment shall be made because of such failure.
See Wilson v. State, 215 Ga. 672, 113 S.E.2d 95 (1960); Edwards v. State, 235 Ga. 603, 221 S.E.2d 28 (1975).

In Flinchum v. State, 141 Ga. App. 59, 232 S.E.2d 396 (1977), only one of three codefendants had introduced evidence of good character. The charge as to the effect of this evidence and limiting it as to the one codefendant was proper.
Whitten v. State, 143 Ga. App. 768, 240 S.E.2d 107 (1977), held that the good character of the defendant is a substantial fact and not an issue or defense.
Morrow v. State, 166 Ga. App. 883, 305 S.E.2d 626 (1983), approved the charge on good character given by the trial judge.

In Millwood v. State, 174 Ga. App. 113, 329 S.E.2d 273 (1985), the defendant requested a charge that good character alone could raise a reasonable doubt of the guilt of the accused. Instead, the judge charged that there must be good character and an additional reasonable doubt. This was error under Shropshire v. State, 81 Ga. 589, 8 S.E. 450 (1888).

In Edwards v. State, 255 Ga. 149, 335 S.E.2d 869 (1985), the court charged the jury that evidence of the defendant's good character could raise a doubt in their minds as to his guilt. “The court also charged that good character is a substantive fact to be considered like any other fact tending to establish innocence. However, good character does not give a license to commit a crime and if evidence of it does not generate a doubt, it will not authorize acquittal.” The Supreme Court upheld this charge and found that the trial court did not err in refusing to give the defendant's charge suggesting that evidence of good character may create such doubt even in the face of apparently conclusive evidence that it could lead jurors to believe the other evidence false or witnesses mistaken.
In Williams v. State, 304 Ga. 455, 818 S.E.2d 653 (2018), the Court upheld the charge on good character evidence which was substantially identical to the suggested pattern jury instruction.

See Etienne v. State, 219 Ga. App. 95, 464 S.E.2d 396 (1995); Smith v. State, 153 Ga. App. 519, 265 S.E.2d 852 (1980); Brooks v. State, 236 Ga. App. 604, 512 S.E.2d 693 (1999) (testimony that defendant had reputation for acting inappropriately toward children not admissible).

State v. Braddy, 254 Ga. 366, 330 S.E.2d 338 (1985) (defendant's testimony that he was a church member, taught Sunday School, was an associate minister of youth at his church, and had never been charged with or convicted of a crime was allowed as evidence of good character); Etienne v. State, 219 Ga. App. 95, 464 S.E.2d 396 (1995).
See Jones v. State, 257 Ga. 753, 363 S.E.2d 529 (1988).
See Kurtz v. State, 287 Ga. App. 823, 652 S.E.2d 858 (2007).
Kurtz v. State, 287 Ga. App. 823, 652 S.E.2d 858 (2007).
Richardson v. State, 173 Ga. App. 695, 327 S.E.2d 813 (1985).
Richardson v. State, 173 Ga. App. 695, 327 S.E.2d 813 (1985).
See Adams v. State, 284 Ga. App. 534, 644 S.E.2d 426 (2007):

Prior to the [2005] enactment of [former] O.C.G.A. § 24-9-84.1, a witness could be impeached by proof of general bad character or by proof that the witness had been convicted of a crime of moral turpitude. Under that rule, theft and shoplifting were considered crimes of moral turpitude. Instead of expressly codifying the existing law, the legislature adopted the language of the federal rule, thus using “dishonesty or false statement” instead of ‘moral turpitude.’ … [C]rimes of “dishonesty” are limited to those crimes that bear upon a witness's propensity to testify truthfully.
See Dempsey v. State, 265 Ga. App. 175, 593 S.E.2d 362 (2004).
Thomas v. State, 291 Ga. App. 795, 662 S.E.2d 849 (2008).

Testimony that the defendant gave the officer his statement “right after he had talked with his parole officer” did not improperly place the defendant's character in issue so as to require mistrial; testimony was only a passing reference to defendant's criminal record. Lanier v. State, 288 Ga. 109, 702 S.E.2d 141 (2010).
Nelson v. State, 204 Ga. App. 409, 419 S.E.2d 502 (1992).
Marshall v. State, 297 Ga. 445, 774 S.E.2d 675 (2015).
Shields v. State, 223 Ga. App. 169, 477 S.E.2d 342 (1996).
See Fed. R. Evid. 404(a).
